meanings.def: the hot gas that water changes into when it boils
examples: Steam rose from the boiling kettle.
a Turkish steam bath
Steam rose from her mug of cocoa.
The hotel has a steam room.
The saucepan puffed little jets of steam.

meanings.def: the power that is produced from steam under pressure, used to operate engines, machines, etc.
examples: the introduction of steam in the 18th century
steam power
the steam age
a steam train/engine
The engine is driven by steam.

meanings.def: very small drops of water that form in the air or on cold surfaces when warm air suddenly cools
examples: She wiped the steam from her glasses.

meanings.def: to get rid of your energy, anger or strong emotions by doing something active or noisy
examples: I went for a long walk to let off steam.
I like blowing off steam and I like saying things that shock people.

meanings.def: with as much speed or energy as possible
examples: Business picked up at the beginning of the year and now it is full steam ahead.
The team is working full steam on the next release.
All of the major players are operating at full steam.

meanings.def: to go somewhere without help from other people
examples: I’ll get to the party under my own steam.

meanings.def: to become gradually more powerful, active, etc.
examples: His election campaign is beginning to get up steam.

meanings.def: to lose energy and enthusiasm and stop doing something, or do it less well

meanings.def: science, technology, engineering, arts and mathematics (used to refer to these subjects as a group in the context of education and jobs)
examples: As a teacher, I'm excited by my school's developing STEAM program.
Our damp clothes steamed in the heat.
a mug of steaming hot coffee

meanings.def: to place food over boiling water so that it cooks in the steam; to be cooked in this way
examples: steamed fish

meanings.def: to move using the power produced by steam
examples: The boat steamed across the lake.
He spotted her steaming down the corridor towards him.
(figurative) The company is steaming ahead with its investment programme.

meanings.def: to be/become very angry or excited about something
examples: You’re getting all steamed up about nothing!

idioms.def: to be/become very angry or excited about something
examples: You’re getting all steamed up about nothing!
